Tasks.Task Description: Set up either GitHub or Azure Repos for your source code control system. This choice will determine your choice of pipeline runner as well. GitHub can use Azure Pipelines or GitHub Actions, whereas Azure Repos must use Azure Pipelines.

Tasks.Task: Set up Azure API Management service
Tasks.Task Description: Set up an Azure API Management service for each API developer so that they can develop API definitions along with the API service. Use the consumption or developer SKU when creating the service.
Use policy fragments to reduce the new policy that developers need to write for each API.
Use named values and backends to ensure that policies are generic and can apply to any API Management instance.
Use the Azure APIOps Toolkit to extract a working API definition from the developer service.
Set up an API approval process that runs on each pull request. The API approval process should include breaking change detection, linting, and automated API testing.
Use the Azure APIOps Toolkit publisher to publish the API to your production API Management service.
From the Azure portal menu, select 'Create a resource'. On the 'Create a resource' page, select 'Integration' > 'API Management'. Enter the required settings and select 'Review + create'.

Tasks.Task: Manage API Management using Azure Automation
Tasks.Task Description: Use Windows PowerShell cmdlets for Azure API Management API within Azure Automation to perform many of your API Management tasks.

Integrate API Management with Azure Key Vault, Azure Monitor, Application Insights, Virtual networks, private endpoints, Application Gateway, Microsoft Entra ID, Event Hubs, and several Azure compute offerings.
Customize the look and feel of the developer portal by adding custom content, customizing styles, and adding your branding. Extend the developer portal further by self-hosting.

Use Azure Resource Management templates, Bicep, Terraform, or Pulumi to create infrastructure resources for API Management. Treat the infrastructure definition as code that you can version, store safely in a source control repository, and trigger a deployment when the definition changes.

Deploy the logic that implements your end-to-end workflows using CI/CD pipelines. Customize pipelines based on the application's needs, review guidance from official documentation, and use sample repositories as a starting point.

Prepare the code with the environment-specific configuration, such as connection strings and references to external resources. Store sensitive values, such as secrets, as reference pointers to entries in a secrets store, such as an Azure key vault.
Package the code for deployment in various environments.
Deploy the packaged code in the destination environment and update the application settings repository with the correct environment values.
Update any required permissions that depend on code.
Get your application ready for execution, if required.
